newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL overnight rate steady on lack of lenders.
newsitem.headline: KL overnight rate steady on lack of lenders.

text.p: The overnight interbank rate was steady at around 7.0 percent on Wednesday due to continued shortage of lenders in the market, dealers said.

"Though the market is quite flush, there are not many lenders," said a dealer at a Malaysian bank. "Banks are also wary about lending lower amid uncertainty over the market direction. This has kept rates steady."
Dealers said a maturity of Bank Negara bills worth 500 million ringgit on Friday will have little impact as the market was supported at the current levels, partly due to reduced activity.
They said they expected the central bank to call for a fresh Bank Negara bill issue next week.

Dealers said there was also a persistent rumour about a possible long-term government bond issue soon, which would mop up liquidity and roll over maturing bonds. A 900-million ringgit long-term government bond issue will mature on May 15.
Earlier, short-term interbank rates were bidded up by finance companies seeking fresh funds, dealers said.
"Finance houses are bidding up rates. A couple of big banks are also believed to be short of funds," said one dealer.
One-week money was unchanged at 6.8/7.0 percent, two-week at 7.10/20 percent against 7.00/10 on Tuesday and three-week at 7.20/25 percent from 7.10/20.
One-month money at 7.25/30 percent, three-month at 7.30/35 and six-month at 7.35/40, were all unchanged.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange fell back after gains on Tuesday.
At 0900 GMT, the benchmark three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) September contract was down one point to 92.68, or an implied yield of 7.32 percent.
December and March 1998 were also down one each to 92.67 and 92.60, or 7.33 and 7.40 percent respectively.
